thread.title: Analysis: The Economic Impact of US Ports
thread.title_full: Analysis: The Economic Impact of US Ports

title: Analysis: The Economic Impact of US Ports
text:
Simulation Emulation Software Analysis: The Economic Impact of US Ports 14 Oct 2015 Cargo Volumes and Throughput , Container Handling , Containers , Finance , Global Economy/Trade , Going Places , Politics , Port Governance , Port Planning , Ports , Shipping An infographic released by the American Association of Port Authorities shows the total economic impact of US ports in 2014, including the positive effects on jobs, total economic value and wages. 
In 2014, US seaports generated more than US$1 million in direct, induced and indirect wages for the whole year. 
Total business output reached a massive $4.4 million in 2014. US ports had previously pledged to spend a total $46 billion in new infrastructure, beginning in 2012. 
Download Zepol's top 20 US ocean port report 
A new wave of investment has recently begun at US ports, with many preparing for the inauguration of the Panama Canal in April, 2016. This investment would help to increase cargo volumes and therefore economic output. 
According to the AAPA, waterborne commerce contributed approximately $4.6 trillion overall to the US economy in 2014 and those same businesses paid nearly $321.1 billion in taxes. 
(Source: John C. Martin, Ph.D. President of Martin Associates / AAPA)
